Application_Facts: Applicant claimed lack of state protection in Mexico; Board failed to consider effectiveness of Mexican state protection and ignored contradictory evidence about corruption and police practices.
Procedural_Issue: Board did not properly assess state protection; failure to consider relevant evidence constitutes procedural error.
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding corruption and police practices in Mexico was presented but ignored by the Board.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board overlooked contradictory evidence on state protection effectiveness.
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied due to insufficient proof of persecution and lack of state protection.
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded for re-determination by a different panel.
Relief_Sought: Proper consideration of state protection in Mexico.
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim by a new IRB panel.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimant must prove lack of state protection, with burden increasing in democratic states.
Decision_Rationale: The Board erred in its analysis by failing to assess the effectiveness of state protection and disregarding key evidence on systemic issues in Mexico.

Crime_Name: Unreasonable Delay in Processing Permanent Residence Application
Legal_Issue: Whether a writ of mandamus is justified due to unreasonable delay in processing a permanent residence application
Evidence_Assessment: Application submitted in 1994; delays until 2003 due to legitimate processes; post-2003 delays included medical, criminal, and security checks; 1.5 years of unaccounted delay not deemed unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonable delay and lack of alternative remedy
Credibility_Factor: Applicant recognized as a Convention refugee, but no evidence of bad faith or intentional delay by authorities
Legal_Rule: Mandamus is granted if there is a public legal duty owed to the applicant, no other adequate remedy, and the delay is unreasonable
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unreasonable delay in processing permanent residence application after refugee status recognition
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; court found delay was not unreasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of application (1994), timeline of processing, reasons for delay (medical, criminal, security checks), duration of unexplained delay (1.5 years)
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law, principles of mandamus, immigration regulations
Defendant_Response: Delays were attributable to necessary background checks and administrative procedures
Remedy_Requested: Writ of mandamus to compel processing of permanent residence application
Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) of the Federal Court Act, R.S.C. 1985, c. F-7

Dispute_Type: Administrative law challenge regarding environmental permit issuance
Legal_Issue: Lawfulness and reasonableness of issuing a water permit under the Canada National Parks Act
Governing_Law: Canada National Parks Act, subsection 8(2); Canadian Environmental Assessment Act
Evidence_Assessment: Environmental assessment conducted, public consultation held, historical water usage data (1995–1998) reviewed, conservation measures evaluated
Decision_Outcome: Water permit upheld as lawful and reasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant (Mountain Parks Watershed Association) to demonstrate unreasonableness or illegality
Credibility_Factor: Parks Canada's expertise and adherence to legislative and procedural requirements
Legal_Rule: Ecological integrity is the first priority under subsection 8(2) of the Canada National Parks Act; environmental assessments required for significant projects
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged impairment of ecological integrity and inadequate public consultation
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed; decision found to be within acceptable range of outcomes
Key_Evidence_Considered: Historical water withdrawal data, environmental impact assessment, public consultation records, conservation measures
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, environmental law, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: Permit issued based on comprehensive assessment and compliance with legal requirements
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, environmental studies, regulatory records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside the water permit decision
Legal_Provision: Subsection 8(2), Canada National Parks Act; Canadian Environmental Assessment Act

Dispute_Type: Refusal of permanent residence application based on financial inadmissibility
Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer properly weighed humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors against inadmissibility under Section 39 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Law: Section 25 and Section 39 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review following refusal of H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to assess H&C factors in relation to inadmissibility; focused on disproportionate hardship without addressing inadmissibility
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; original decision quashed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate that H&C factors outweigh inadmissibility, but officer must properly assess both sides
Credibility_Factor: Claims of domestic abuse and humanitarian grounds were raised but not adequately assessed
Legal_Rule: Section 25 requires weighing H&C factors against inadmissibility; binding effect of Justice Hughes' Order
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, compliance with prior court orders
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to follow Justice Hughes' Order, improper assessment of H&C versus inadmissibility
Outcome_on_Merits: Success on judicial review due to procedural error and failure to apply correct legal framework
Key_Evidence_Considered: Domestic abuse claims, financial inadmissibility, humanitarian and compassionate factors
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, court precedents, prior judicial orders
Defendant_Response: PRRA officer did not address inadmissibility in light of H&C factors as required
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal affidavits, legal submissions
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision and remittal for redetermination
Outcome: Decision remitted to a different officer for reassessment in accordance with Justice Hughes' Order

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to family targeting and political activity
Procedural_Issue: Fresh evidence post-decision was deemed inadmissible
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting persecution claims
Credibility_Assessment: IRB found the applicant not credible
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, IRB’s decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of IRB's negative credibility finding
Decision_Rationale: IRB's decision was reasonable and supported by evidence

Violation_Type: Failure to meet definition of Convention refugee
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Definition of Convention refugee
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, IRPA, s. 96-98
Application_Facts: Applicant born in Russia, resided in Latvia, claimed statelessness and persecution; court found she was entitled to Russian citizenship through a simple formality (passport stamp); no evidence of persecution in Russia
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee status in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Applicant residing in Latvia, outside country of nationality (Russia)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Board's decision
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding eligibility for Russian citizenship, lack of proof of persecution in Russia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of actual persecution in Russia
Claim of statelessness not substantiated due to entitlement to Russian citizenship
Credibility_Assessment: Court found claim of statelessness unconvincing due to available access to Russian citizenship
Relief_Sought: Stay in Canada under protected status
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Board’s negative determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Applicant has effective nationality (Russia), can avail herself of state protection, and failed to demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution

Legal_Issue: Is the '753 Patent eligible for inclusion on the Patent Register under the Regulations?
Evidence_Assessment: Claims analyzed, evidence reviewed, legal precedents considered
Legal_Rule: A patent must contain a claim for the medicine itself or its use to be eligible for inclusion
Grounds_for_Claim: '753 Patent relates to a delivery system, not a claim to lansoprazole or its use
Outcome_on_Merits: Patent not eligible; prohibition application dismissed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Patent claims, description of delivery system, applicability to lansoprazole
Legal_Framework: Regulations, statutory interpretation, patent law principles
Defendant_Response: Novopharm sought dismissal based on ineligibility
Outcome: Application dismissed; Novopharm and Takeda awarded costs

Legal_Issue: Whether Procter & Gamble is entitled to an interlocutory injunction for alleged patent infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits from experts, lack of product sample, cross-examinations
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must show: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff established a prima facie case; defendant failed to refute evidence convincingly
Legal_Rule: Three-part test for interlocutory injunction: (a) serious issue to be tried, (b) irreparable harm, (c) balance of convenience favors plaintiff
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of patent by Colgate's Ultra Fleecy product prior to patent expiry
Outcome_on_Merits: Not determined; injunction granted pending trial or expiration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Expert affidavits, market launch plans, patent claims
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law and equitable principles for injunctive relief
Defendant_Response: Denied infringement; argued lack of evidence and no demonstrated harm
Remedy_Requested: Interlocutory injunction to prevent sale of Ultra Fleecy
Outcome: Injunction granted; Colgate prohibited from selling Ultra Fleecy until patent expired
Legal_Provision: Interlocutory injunction provisions under Canadian equity and patent law
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over intellectual property disputes

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer breached procedural fairness due to missing documents in the CTR
Evidence_Assessment: Missing documents in the CTR were assessed as not material to the decision
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Legal_Rule: Officers must adhere to procedural fairness; missing documents may lead to judicial review if material
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, implied by judicial review context
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of procedural fairness due to missing documents in CTR
Key_Evidence_Considered: Education documents not submitted despite extension
Legal_Framework: Procedural fairness under administrative law and IRPA
Defendant_Response: Officer's decision upheld due to applicant's failure to submit required documents
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (education documents), Certified Tribunal Record (CTR)
Remedy_Requested: Setting aside the decision via judicial review
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 397 of the Federal Court Rules
Application_Facts: The Minister sought reconsideration of a July 20, 2004 order permitting Tatiana Lazareva's application for permanent residence to be assessed in Canada; the Court had previously ruled against removal to Russia.
Procedural_Issue: Motion for reconsideration under Rule 397 based on new arguments by the Minister
Jurisdictional_Issue: Court's authority to direct Minister's actions under IRPA and prevent frustration of its orders
Evidence_Used: Arguments regarding Russia's acceptance of Lazareva, legality of prohibiting removal
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No inadvertent error found; new arguments not grounds for reconsideration
Outcome: Original Court order stands; Minister must process Lazareva's application in Canada
Relief_Sought: Reconsideration of prior order by the Minister
Remedy_Sought: Court to alter or set aside its previous decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Rule 397 allows reconsideration only for inadvertent errors, not for appeals or new legal arguments
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, as it involves questions of jurisdiction and interpretation of court rules
Decision_Rationale: The Court found no error in its prior decision; the Minister's arguments did not meet the threshold for reconsideration under Rule 397; the Court has jurisdiction to ensure its orders are not frustrated
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court, Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 175(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant challenged visa officer's decision on marriage validity based on religion; Board assessed applicant's Hindu status and admission of post-hearing documents.
Procedural_Issue: Board did not admit post-hearing documents; adequacy of explanation for late submission considered.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inadequate explanation for late submission of documents; failure to prove Hindu status
Credibility_Assessment: Board favored CAIPS notes over applicant's testimony in determining religious affiliation
Decision_Outcome: Board concluded applicant was not Hindu and did not breach procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: No procedural fairness breach due to lack of justification for late documents; factual finding on religion supported by record

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of awareness and indirect support
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible based on continued service despite knowledge

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim exclusion
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F of the Refugee Convention, incorporated via IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Awareness of and indirect support for crimes against humanity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International law, Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, IRPA

Legal_Issue: Whether reasonable grounds existed to believe tax collection would be jeopardized by delay
Governing_Law: s. 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Procedural_Stage: Review of ex parte jeopardy collection order
Evidence_Assessment: Assignment of Services MLM's most valuable asset to offshore company Wellgate with no Canadian assets
Burden_of_Proof: Crown must justify the jeopardy order; applicant bears burden to show lack of reasonable grounds
Credibility_Factor: Concerns over asset dissipation due to offshore transfer
Legal_Rule: A judge may authorize immediate tax collection under s. 225.2(2) if delay would jeopardize collection
Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe jeopardy to collection
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of asset dissipation following transfer to offshore entity
Outcome_on_Merits: Jeopardy collection order upheld as justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Transfer of assets to Wellgate, an offshore company without Canadian assets
Defendant_Response: Services MLM challenged the ex parte order, arguing lack of reasonable grounds and inadequate disclosure
Remedy_Requested: Review and cancellation of the ex parte jeopardy collection order
Outcome: Ex parte jeopardy collection order confirmed; challenge dismissed

Violation_Type: Denial of refugee status based on credibility issues
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed political persecution in Haiti; principal applicant's testimony contained contradictions, such as obtaining a birth certificate during alleged detention
Claimant_Status: Principal applicant and spouse seeking refugee status
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent testimony by principal applicant affecting credibility
Procedural_Issue: Board disregarded corroborative evidence due to credibility concerns
Evidence_Used: Testimony of principal applicant, supporting statement from spouse
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony undermined reliability of evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board found principal applicant not credible due to material inconsistencies
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision denying refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in assessing Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision fell within range of acceptable outcomes; credibility findings supported by record
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Application_Facts: The applicant was threatened multiple times by a gang over several months in El Salvador.
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee protection in Canada
Procedural_Issue: RPD's assessment of personal risk was found to be manifestly unreasonable
Evidence_Used: Specific threats made by a gang against the applicant
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD treated specific threats as generalized risk without sufficient justification
Relief_Sought: Refugee protection based on personal risk upon return to El Salvador
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of claim by another RPD member
Decision_Rationale: The RPD erred in concluding the risk was generalized despite specific, repeated threats indicating a personal risk
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board - Refugee Protection Division (IRB-RPD)

Mitigating_Factors: Police provided advice to report future incidents, referral to crisis desk
Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to domestic context
Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable findings by tribunal
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 96; Presumption of State Protection

Aggravating_Factors: Repeated incidents, lack of effective intervention
Mitigating_Factors: Police response included referrals and advice to report further incidents
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient for review, insufficient to rebut presumption
Evidence_Type: Applicant testimony, documentary evidence of reporting
Credibility_Assessment: Accepted with some reservations by tribunal
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96; Women's Protection Principles in International Law

Sub_Crime_Type: Marital Rape within Domestic Violence Context
Aggravating_Factors: Occurred within coercive domestic relationship, underreporting due to fear
Mitigating_Factors: Existence of legal framework and new laws addressing domestic violence
Evidence_Sufficiency: Limited direct evidence, based on testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Considered but not sufficient to overturn state protection presumption
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 97(1); CEDAW, Istanbul Convention principles

Aggravating_Factors: Part of pattern of coercive control, removal of children without consent
Mitigating_Factors: No evidence of harm to children, possible civil custody dispute element
Credibility_Assessment: Accepted as plausible but not determinative
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96; Hague Convention principles on child abduction

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant did not maintain sufficient physical presence in Canada; claimed humanitarian grounds but lacked supporting justification
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – insufficient time spent in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness regarding right to cross-examine author of adverse document
Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld; permanent residency deemed invalid
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of procedural unfairness and quashing of IAD decision
Decision_Rationale: Applicant was given full opportunity to respond to allegations, explain circumstances, and present witnesses; no breach of procedural fairness occurred

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of internal flight alternative (IFA) given daughter's medical needs
Evidence_Assessment: Barriers to accessing cancer treatment in Mumbai for the applicant's daughter
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found IFA determination unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate risk, but officer must reasonably assess IFA
Credibility_Factor: Medical evidence regarding daughter’s health and treatment requirements
Legal_Rule: IFA test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution; (2) conditions not unreasonable to seek refuge internally
Grounds_for_Claim: Specialized medical needs make Mumbai an unreasonable IFA
Key_Evidence_Considered: Medical reports on daughter’s cancer treatment needs, healthcare access in Mumbai
Legal_Framework: PRRA process, s. 97 and s. 112 of IRPA, case law on IFA
Defendant_Response: Officer asserted Mumbai was a viable IFA
Evidence_Type: Documentary medical evidence, country condition information
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision remitted to a different officer

Risk_Assessment: Assessed for general violence, not sexual offending
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of non-sexual violent behavior
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ refusal based on lack of sexual offense conviction deemed reasonable

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of requiring sex offender assessment for PFVs
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of Commissioner’s discretion and statutory alignment
Legal_Rule: Reasonable limits permitted under Act for safety
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of prisoner rights and program participation
Defendant_Response: Denial of PFVs based on non-compliance with assessment

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of right to family visits without just cause
Legal_Framework: Statutory rights and procedural fairness in corrections system
Risk_Factor: Perceived risk based on unconvicted allegations
Credibility: Edwards’ compliance with other programs enhances credibility
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate due to completed violence program

Risk_Assessment: Low sexual risk, moderate general violence risk
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to assess general risk but not sexual risk
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ position considered credible given voluntary program principles

Evidence_Sufficiency: Strong evidence of violent past, none for sexual misconduct
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ argument supported by statutory principles

Evidence_Sufficiency: Adequate to justify concern but not specialized assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Edwards’ stance aligned with voluntary participation principle
Applicant's position found reasonable
Decision_Rationale: Requirement for sex offender assessment not justified without sexual offense conviction
Authority_Responsible: Commissioner of Correctional Service of Canada

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of ministerial certificate
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Minister's certificate alleging terrorist affiliation
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Federal Court review under s. 40.1 of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessed on balance of probabilities; included confidential intelligence and testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Singh's denials were deemed incongruous and not credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Court must determine if there are reasonable grounds to believe membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Minister issued certificate based on security intelligence reports
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial support to families of hijackers
Sheltering wife of former BK leader
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denials presented but found not credible
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to challenge the certificate
Crimes.Outcome: Certificate upheld; Singh considered inadmissible under immigration law

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Affiliation with BK/BKI, a designated Sikh militant group
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: High risk based on close associations and support activities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Sustained contact with known militants and leadership figures
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Supportive and associative conduct indicating membership
Crimes.Target_Entity: Canadian national security and immigration integrity
Admission_or_Involvement: Sheltered wife of former BK leader
Received calls from Wadawa Singh Babbar
Had significant ties with BK/BKI leaders
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No formal leadership role established, but active supporter
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Court found applicant's explanations inconsistent and lacking credibility
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Credibility of Singh’s denials versus intelligence and circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Denials deemed incongruous and not credible
Credibility_Factors: Lack of plausible explanation for contacts
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to ministerial certificate on judicial review
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Declared inadmissible; subject to removal from Canada

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Support for a proscribed terrorist organization
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Endangerment through material and logistical support
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to sustained connections and supportive acts
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Association with individuals involved in violent extremism
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Non-combat support including shelter, communication, and financial aid
Admission_or_Involvement: Provided indirect support to militant network
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Supporter without evidence of operational command
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Applicant’s explanations rejected due to inconsistency
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Weight given to classified evidence and behavioral patterns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Denials lacked plausibility and coherence
Credibility_Factors: Actions consistent with support for militant cause
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – terrorism-related inadmissibility
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of national security certificate
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Certified as inadmissible; threat to national security confirmed

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether Mr. Liang was a legitimate businessman or a criminal fleeing prosecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant, Mr. Liang, should be excluded as a refugee under Article 1F(b) due to serious reasons for considering he committed a non-political crime
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Mr. Liang excluded as a refugee
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The board found Mr. Liang's story implausible and favored the Minister's evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Mr. Liang entered Canada using a purchased Dominican passport and claimed refugee status, citing political persecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is there sufficient evidence to prove Mr. Liang possessed false identity documents under the applicable standard?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian law and 'serious reasons for considering' standard under refugee law
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification of additional questions

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Accused of being involved in organized criminal activity
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Minister's evidence, credibility assessment, expert testimony
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1F(b) of the UN Refugee Convention

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Mr. Liang claimed refugee status, arguing persecution due to false charges in China. The Canadian government sought his exclusion based on alleged criminal activity
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F(b) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mr. Liang's application for judicial review was dismissed; excluded as a refugee

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Mr. Liang sought refugee status in Canada, claiming persecution for refusing to bribe officials. Canadian authorities disputed his claim based on alleged criminal activity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Liang committed bribery as part of a serious non-political crime outside Canada
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Serious reasons for considering – lower than balance of probabilities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Confessions and expert testimonies questioning document authenticity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Article 1F(b) of the UN Refugee Convention

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpol warrant for conspiracy to commit murder, leading a criminal organization, and corruption scandal in China
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1F(b) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no certification of general importance question

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Mr. Liang claimed refugee status, alleging persecution, while the Canadian government sought his exclusion due to alleged corruption and organized crime involvement

Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged politically motivated charges in China
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Accused leader of a criminal organization in China

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over the standard of proof and credibility of evidence in refugee status determination

Crime_Name: Immigration-related claims (refugee status and humanitarian grounds)
Dispute_Type: Procedural and substantive review of PRRA and H&C decisions
Legal_Issue: Failure to hold a hearing, application of incorrect legal tests, ignoring evidence
Credibility_Assessment: No central credibility concerns raised in decision
Evidence_Type: Claims of domestic violence in Turkey, lack of corroborative evidence
Legal_Provision: PRRA: Adequate state protection test; H&C: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship test
Basis_of_Claim: Risk of domestic violence in Turkey
Application_Error: Alleged failure to hold hearing and misapplication of legal tests
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for procedural issues, correctness for legal tests
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for procedural fairness, correctness for legal interpretation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of duty to answer truthfully under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of administrative decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision was based on sufficient evidence and procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 16; Federal Courts Rules, Rule 17(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Perceived lack of credibility due to contradictions with spouse's statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Contradictory interview statements, missing interview notes
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 16 IRPA, Rule 17(b) Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose material used in decision-making
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of wife's interview notes in certified record
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in spousal accounts of combat involvement

Crimes.Crime_Name: Suspected involvement in combat leading to inadmissibility to Canada
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the decision was supported by clear evidence and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Contradictions between applicant and spouse’s statements on combat involvement
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to satisfy admissibility criteria
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Discrepancies in personal statements about military activity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Decisions must be based on disclosed, credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA framework on inadmissibility and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Interview transcripts, application forms
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Setting aside of decision and re-hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to inadmissibility and fairness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa refusal based on credibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal based on alleged misrepresentation violated procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 16; Federal Courts Rules, Rule 17(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged untruthfulness due to inconsistencies with spouse’s account
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Undisclosed interview notes, application responses
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 16 IRPA, Rule 17(b) Federal Courts Rules
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of undisclosed evidence in determining misrepresentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to provide applicant access to spouse's interview notes
Crimes.Application_Error: Determining misrepresentation without disclosure of key evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Wife's interview notes not provided to applicant
Crimes.Application_Factor: Contradictions regarding contact with spouse and combat history
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Set aside and remanded to new officer

Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA Officer reasonably assess the psychological evidence and hardship claims in the H&C Application?
Governing_Law: Reasonableness is the standard for reviewing H&C decisions
Outcome: The PRRA Officer's decision was unreasonable due to insufficient consideration of mental health aspects
Credibility_Assessment: The PRRA Officer accepted the PTSD diagnosis
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Mental health impacts, particularly PTSD, and emotional hardship upon return to Mexico
Application_Error: Failed to adequately analyze emotional hardships and implications of PTSD
Evidence_Ignored: Key aspects of the psychological report regarding emotional hardship
Legal_Standard: Hardship must be unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate
Application_Factor: Potential psychological deterioration if returned to Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for fresh determination

Governing_Law: Standard of review for H&C applications is reasonableness
Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and sought permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer failed to properly assess mental health evidence
Evidence_Used: Psychologist's report indicating severe mental health issues
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to address impact of returning to Mexico on mental health
Credibility_Assessment: Diagnosis accepted but implications not assessed
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision quashed and remanded for re-assessment
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Rationale: Inadequate assessment of mental health evidence and hardship

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Visa refusal based on credibility and admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can section 11 of the Act be a basis for visa refusal without specific inadmissibility findings?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 11(1) and 40(1)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's inconsistent statements and discrepancies with family testimonies undermined credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Inconsistent oral statements, conflicting family testimonies
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Doubt about non-inadmissibility due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide consistent and credible information
Crimes.Application_Factor: Credibility and consistency of applicant’s statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to answer truthfully as per section 16(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Untruthful and evasive responses during interview
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 16(1) and 11(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Inconsistent and vague responses regarding work history, family displacement, and LTTE involvement
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and consistent testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant not credible due to inconsistencies and evasiveness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to answer truthfully under section 16(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to meet burden of proving non-inadmissibility due to lack of credibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Residence Requirement Violation under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether applicant met residence requirements under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the citizenship judge provide sufficient reasons and did the applicant meet the residence condition under the Citizenship Act?
Crimes.Outcome: The decision was unreasonable due to unclear reasoning and unaddressed evidence gaps. The matter was remitted for redetermination.
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Contradictions in travel records and insufficient documentation were not addressed by the judge.
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Travel records, residency documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Applicant must accumulate at least three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding the application.
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to meet physical presence or intention test for residency
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Unclear application of residency test (intention vs. physical presence)
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient clarification on which residency test was applied
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictions in travel records, lack of supporting documents
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residence duration and pattern within four-year period
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside and remitted for reassessment

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Raphaël’s citizenship application raised concerns about her residency claims, including travel record discrepancies and incomplete documentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the citizenship judge provide sufficient reasons for approving Raphaël's citizenship application?
Crimes.Outcome: The decision was unreasonable due to lack of clarity and failure to address key issues; the case is remitted for redetermination.
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Use of vague language ('seems') and failure to resolve inconsistencies in evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Travel records, residency documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Applicant must meet residence conditions under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false representation through inaccurate or misleading residency claims
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Unaddressed contradictions in travel history and documentation gaps
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review by the Federal Court on appeal by the Minister
Crimes.Application_Error: Approval despite significant evidentiary gaps and credibility concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Significant gaps in evidence, including travel record discrepancies
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applies to adequacy of reasons and factual findings
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency verification and truthfulness of representations
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Original decision overturned and referred back for reassessment
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Incomplete or potentially misleading documentation submitted

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection eligibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1E of the Convention
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1E of the United Nations Convention on the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant misrepresented himself with a purchased Greek passport
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Permanent Residence Permit, claims of Kurdish ethnicity, new evidence on loss of status

Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to prove loss of status or inability to renew documents
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Claims of inability to reacquire documents without supporting proof
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Substantially similar rights and obligations to nationals
Crimes.Application_Factor: Access to work, return rights, health services in Greece

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection eligibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Exclusion from refugee protection under Article 1E of the Convention

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Greek Permanent Residence Permit granted substantial rights
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show loss of status or inability to reacquire documents
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: False entry into Canada and claim based on Kurdish ethnicity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1E excludes those with rights akin to nationality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Seeking refugee status despite established residence rights in Greece
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Permanent Residence Permit, lack of proof of lost status
Crimes.Legal_Framework: UN Convention relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed refugee status based on ethnicity despite legal residence in Greece
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Residence permit, application records

Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in organization linked to terrorism

Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency and detail of reports on MQM's activities
